author: Bob E.

review: We have used this for about a week now. The apps we have tested it with are Netflix, Amazon VOD, Youtube and Twitch. It comes nicely packaged with everything you need to set it up. Note you will need an outlet handy as it must be plugged into an outlet for a power source. I did not measure the provided AC cord exactly but it is around 6-8 feet. It barely made the AC outlet as I have the TV mounted on a wall. Once plugged in and the TV is set to the correct hdmi port, set up was a breeze. It somehow knew I ordered it as it came up with my Amazon account. Keep this in mind if you send one as a gift. Mind you, I did not note this was a gift so it may behave differently if you order as a gift. I found it easily detected my 2.4  (5/5 bars)and 5 (3/5 bars) ghz wireless N networks. The signal strength shown is better than the Samsung Bluray player in the same location. Since there was 3 bars for 5 ghz, I used that to see how well it would work. Next it will install updates which took a pretty long time. I did not time it but I would estimate it was around 10 minutes. Much longer than I expected. It will reboot and then bring you to a tutorial screen. I could not find a way to skip this so you must sit through it. You are now ready to use it. I selected Netflix for the first try as this is what the family uses the most. Installed the app in a very short time. Login is the same as any other Netflix interface I have used. App worked wonderfully! Then tried Amazon VOD, Youtube and Twitch which were excellent. The main reason I got this was to use for streaming via wireless. My router is on the main floor opposite side of the house. This is located in a bedroom on the second floor. Distance is about 40-50 feet. I did not really expect 5 ghz N to work well but it has so far. Now the Samsung Bluray is for playing movies. The router is an Asus RT-N56U for those that are interested. A very good router that has served me well for years. And, my wife really likes the remote and how the Fire TV Stick works.
author: Poocher

review: Out of the box, it took 2+ hours to set up because it detected an update... it tried to update and failed 8 times.. contacted tech support.  After nearly an hour with tech support, the download actually worked.  Once it was upgraded, the device seems to work ok.  The lower score is because the initial experience was really really poor.  You don't expect to take an item out of the box and take so much time to get it to work.  By example, the Roku only took about 2 minutes before I could do something with it on the same TV.Side note: Because it took so long to download the update, and the screen doesn't change during download, there was a burn in problem with the text on the screen.  You probably will want to chose a different input with video or something playing that doesn't burn the screen if your TV could be burned in (like plazma tvs).

author: Amanda

review: The Fire TV Stick is a nice device when compared to Google Chromecast. It's VERY fast and requires almost no buffering, which is awesome. You can tell it has the dual core CPU! The one gripe for me (and it's pretty major) is that they aren't really clear that first gen Fire HD 7 tablet's won't work with the fling (screen mirroring) feature. You have to have a newer HD 7 table that has the "fire OS". since this is the main reason I got it to use with my Comcast TV app to use a second bedroom, it's kinda a deal breaker. They currently have no iPhone app to fling (only remote app) which I could've done with google Chomecast. Amazon support says they have no information on when or even "if" an app will be released to fling from iPhone. Bottom line is that it is a great device for what it is and I'm keeping it (since I got it for $20). If I had paid full price I'd be returning it and getting a Chromecast so I could actually use my Comcast TV app in the bedroom.
